feed.title: Combined summary - Fwd: Bitcoin Core 0.12.0 release schedule

entry.title: Combined summary - Fwd: Bitcoin Core 0.12.0 release schedule
entry.summary: On October 1, 2015, Marcel Jamin raised a question on the bitcoin-dev mailing list asking why Bitcoin versioning does not follow the SemVer spec. Btc Drak responded that they do follow the SemVer spec using a.b.c for major versions and 0.12.0 as the next major version. Bitcoin's relevance was also questioned due to its volatile value and increasing competition from other cryptocurrencies. However, Bitcoin's decentralized nature, versatility, and established reputation have helped it remain a relevant and widely used digital currency.In a recent email exchange, Marcel Jamin asked Wladimir J. van der Laan why Bitcoin Core software is still at version 0.11.1. Van der Laan responded that most of the investment in the network is not in the Bitcoin Core software, but in things building on top of it. The assumption being made is that nothing really stupid will happen to the network/protocol and that it will not go down. The Bitcoin Core team recently released an API that makes implementing a full node practical, a reasonably usable Bitcoin Core GUI for non-technical people, and a reasonably safe wallet through the Bitcoin Core Daemon. However, the backup-resistant accounting system currently blocks the last feature. Luke also contributed to the discussion on this topic.A question was raised by Marcel Jamin on the bitcoin-dev mailing list regarding why Bitcoin versioning does not follow the SemVer spec. Btc Drak responded, stating that they do follow the SemVer spec using a.b.c for major versions and 0.12.0 as the next major version. Maintenance releases are labeled as 0.12.1 and so on, while release candidates are labeled as 0.12.0-rc1. However, an HTML attachment in the email thread was scrubbed, so there is no further information available from it.Wladimir J. van der Laan and Marcel Jamin had a conversation about the Bitcoin protocol's version numbering, where Jamin suggested using version numbers as a signaling mechanism. Van der Laan responded by pointing out that most of the investment in Bitcoin is not in the Bitcoin Core software. The highest network protocol version is 70011, whereas the block/transaction versions are at v3/v1, respectively. Van der Laan explained that it's mostly due to not using the numbers as a signaling mechanism and the potential arguments that would arise from considering whether the software is mature enough to be called 1.0.0. In conclusion, while Bitcoin faces challenges from newer competitors, its established reputation and large user base give it an advantage over them.
